Effect of anabatic winds on settlements
Anabatic winds take pollution out of the valley.
Effects of katabatic winds on settlements
Katabatic winds trap pollution in the valley.
Katabatic winds bring cold temperatures to the valley.
Katabatic winds lead to the development of the thermal belt (zone of
warmer temperature above the valley floor) and a frost pocket (an area of
very cold temperatures at the bottom of a valley where frost occurs) in a
valley at night. This is shown in Figure 1.4.1C.
In the exam, you may be asked to draw, label or describe how
anabatic or katabatic winds form in valleys. Learn to redraw and

1 Anabatic and katabatic winds
The structure of a valley and the heating and cooling that occurs during

Chapters.Title: 16  CHAPTER
Text:
of Basic Education 2014
16  CHAPTER 1 CLIMATE AND WEATHER 
Mind the Gap CAPS Grade 12 Geography
Chapter
1
1.4 Local climate (valley and 
city climate)
Valley climate occurs on a local scale and lasts for a few hours. In this 
section we will focus on:
â¢ 
Anabatic and katabatic winds
â¢ 
Aspect
1.4.1 Anabatic and katabatic winds
The structure of a valley and the heating and cooling that occurs during  
a day cause anabatic and katabatic winds to occur. This is shown in 
Figures 1.4.1A and 1.4.1B.
Figure 1.4.1A: Anabatic winds 
                                     Figure 1.4.1B: Katabatic winds
Airflow
During the day, 
the slopes and 
air above them 
are heated
Warm, less 
dense air rises 
up the valley 
sides, forming 
anabatic winds
Anabatic winds (day)
Katabatic winds (night)
Effect of anabatic winds on settlements
â¢ 
Anabatic winds take pollution out of the valley.
Effects of katabatic winds on settlements
â¢ 
Katabatic winds trap pollution in the valley.
â¢ 
Katabatic winds bring cold temperatures to the valley.
Katabatic winds lead to the development of the thermal belt (zone of 
warmer temperature above the valley floor) and a frost pocket (an area of 
very cold temperatures at the bottom of a valley where frost occurs) in a 
valley at night. This is shown in Figure 1.4.1C.
At night, the 
slopes and air 
above them 
are cooled
Cold, dense 
air subsides 
down the valley 
slopes forming 
katabatic 
winds
warm thermal belt
Anabatic means  
âmoving upwardâ and 
katabatic means  
âgoing downhillâ.
 In the exam, you may be asked to draw, label or describe how 
anabatic or katabatic winds form in valleys. Learn to redraw and 
label Figures 1.4.1A and 1.4.1B below.
PAY SPECIAL ATTENTION
